Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Methadone for Opioid-Sparing in Pediatric Tonsillectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: This double-blind, randomised controlled trial was conducted in a pediatric surgical setting.

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were children aged 3-17 years undergoing tonsillectomy.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either a single intravenous dose of methadone (0.1 mg/kg or 0.15 mg/kg) or as-needed fentanyl.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was total opioid use over 7 days, measured in oral morphine equivalents per kilogram (OME/kg).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty children were randomised (20 per group)

Result_Outcome.evidence: Total 7-day opioid use was significantly lower in the methadone groups: 0.9 [0.1,1.4] OME/kg for 0.1 mg/kg (P=0.045) and 0.5 [0,1.4] OME/kg for 0.15 mg/kg (P=0.023), compared to 1.5 [1.2,2.1] OME/kg in controls.

Harms.evidence: No serious opioid-related adverse events occurred.
